importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Date of the most recent Trump-Putin phone call that led to the announcement of a planned summit in Budapest.
Date of the previous Trump-Putin summit in Alaska, where initial ceasefire conditions were discussed and agreed upon.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Trump's claim that a summit could happen within two weeks has been challenged by Moscow, casting doubt on near-term feasibility.

keyTakeAways: Doubts have emerged over the likelihood of a swift Trump-Putin summit in Budapest to discuss a ceasefire in Ukraine.
The Kremlin has stated there is no precise timeframe for the summit, with preparations requiring significant time.
Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov and US counterpart Marco Rubio were scheduled to meet for preparatory talks but have been tabled, indicating potential disagreements on ceasefire conditions.
Russia maintains that its demands—such as territorial concessions and Ukraine's neutrality—remain unchanged since the Alaska summit, rejecting calls for a ceasefire.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and European leaders have accused Russia of stalling, claiming that violence continues despite promises of peace.
Trump has proposed freezing battle lines as a starting point for negotiations, a position supported by Ukraine and Europe, but rejected by Putin.
Russia has ruled out direct talks with Ukraine’s president until a peace deal is practically agreed upon, deepening the diplomatic divide.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin is the central figure in the planned summit with Donald Trump, and his position on ceasefire demands directly influences the prospects of peace.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump has publicly advocated for a rapid ceasefire and a meeting with Putin, making him a key political player in the peace process.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rubio was scheduled to meet with Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov to discuss pre-summit conditions, and the cancellation of that meeting signals friction between US and Russian diplomacy.

namedEntities.name: Sergey Lavrov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lavrov is a key Russian negotiator who has rejected US ceasefire proposals and reaffirmed Russia’s hardline positions from the Alaska summit.

namedEntities.name: Dmitry Peskov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Peskov has publicly downplayed expectations for a summit, emphasizing no set timeframe and the need for serious preparation.

namedEntities.name: Sergei Ryabkov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ryabkov stated it is premature to discuss details of preparatory talks, indicating Russian caution and strategic ambiguity.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelenskyy
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelenskyy has consistently opposed Russian demands and called for direct talks with Putin, highlighting Ukraine’s commitment to peace.

namedEntities.name: Budapest
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The city is the proposed location for a high-level Trump-Putin summit, and its selection underscores geopolitical significance as a neutral site for negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Alaska Summit
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The prior Alaska summit set early ceasefire expectations, which Russia has now reaffirmed as unchanged, forming the basis of current negotiations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Doubts are growing over a potential Trump-Putin summit in Budapest aimed at achieving a ceasefire in Ukraine. The Kremlin has downplayed expectations of an imminent meeting, citing no precise timeframe and the need for extensive preparation. Reports indicate a planned preparatory meeting between Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov and US counterpart Marco Rubio has been canceled, reflecting possible divergent views on ceasefire conditions. Russia maintains its hardline demands—such as territorial concessions and Ukraine’s neutrality—unchanged since the Alaska summit, while Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and European leaders accuse Moscow of stalling and continuing military aggression. Trump’s call for a frozen battle line has drawn support from Ukraine and allies, but has been rejected by Putin. Russia has also ruled out direct talks with Zelenskyy until a peace deal is practically agreed upon, deepening the diplomatic impasse.
title: Doubts emerge over Trump-Putin Budapest summit
